results.title: Daily miracle
results.creator_credit: Norman A. Uren and Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows how the newspaper “The West Australian” is set up and printed. The film shows all stages of production, from setting of type which is then checked in the reading room to the final printing on rolls which contain over 120 miles of newsprint. Demonstrates how a big newspaper works, and its reliance on other world sources of news.

results.title: Daily life of the Bozo people
results.creator_credit: International Film Foundation and Hermann Schlenker
results.brief_description: A documentary account of a typical day for the Bozo tribe in Mali, West Africa. Environmental demands are met through a classic division of labour determined in large part by the annual fluctuations of the River Niger. Shows the people as they wash, weave, fish, cook and eat. Without narration - natural sounds only.

results.title: Daily bread
results.brief_description: Although Britain grows grain, most of the flour needed to make the bread which feeds the people of the British Isles is imported from overseas. This film follows the processes of manufacture from the time that the flour is unloaded in the ports until it leaves the baker’s van in the delivery-man’s basket.

results.title: Daguerre: the birth of photography = Daguerre: ou la naissan
results.brief_description: Traces the early history of photography, concentrating on the achievements of Joseph Niepce, who in 1822 invented the first permanent photograph. Louis Daguerre, who in 1838, developed a process for recording photographs on polished metal plates is shown with other innovators in the field.
results.title_for_label: Daguerre: the birth of photography = Daguerre: ou la naissan

results.title: Daddy long legs (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Samuel G. Engel, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Jean Negulesco
results.brief_description: A remake of the 1931 film, but greatly expanded to allow for the dancing of Fred Astaire and Leslie Caron. The story is that of a French orphan whose schooling is sponsored by an American millionaire, on the stipulation that she will never know who he is. His secretary (Thelma Ritter) is so touched by her letters of gratitude, delivered by the school, that she persuades him to visit. He is then enchanted by the elegant, lovely girl and falls in love with her - and she with him, without knowing who he is. The film contains a wide range of music including a jazz with drums by Astaire, a ballet danced by Caron, several dream sequences with Astaire imagining himself as a playboy and a rich cowboy, and Johnny Mercer’s memorable song ‘Something’s Gotta Give’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Samuel G. Engel, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Jean Negulesco

results.title: Dad and Dave: on our selection
results.creator_credit: ICON, Anthony Buckley Productions, AFFC, Anthony Buckley, Bruce Davey and George Whaley
results.brief_description: Steele Rudd’s classic Dad and Dave stories represent what is both noble and comic in colonial society. The Rudd’s are a loud, unconventional farming family, ekeing out a living in the harsh conditions of the bush with little respect for authority. Stereotypical “fair dinkum Aussies”, Dad’s blustering and Ma’s stoicism hold the family together. This film features the talents of an all-star cast including Leo McKern, Dame Joan Sutherland, Geoffrey Rush, Ray Barrett, Nicholas Eadie, Noah Taylor and Barry Otto, with songs and music by Peter Best.

results.title: Dad and Dave come to town
results.brief_description: The third film in Cinesound’s ‘Dad and Dave’ series, this film had virtually nothing in common with the Steele Rudd stories and instead was based upon one of Ken Hall’s favourite comic formulae of the ‘fish out of water’. The Rudd family are taken from their usual rural haunts to the city when Dad unexpectedly inherits a women’s fashion emporium. Cast includes Bert Bailey, Shirley Ann Richards, Peter Finch, Fred MacDonald, Billy Rayes, Alec Kellaway, Sidney Wheeler, Connie Martyn, Ossie Wenban, Valerie Scanlan, Muriel Flood, Leila Steppe, Marshall Crosby, Cecil Perry, Billy Stewart, Marie D’Alton and Leslie Victor.

results.title: Dad's house, mum's house
results.brief_description: Shared custody, co-parenting, share-parenting…it goes by different names. The children may move back and forth between parents, or one parent may retain day-to-day care…its form varies from family to family. Joint custody allows both parents to participate in major decisions affecting their child’s health, education and welfare.
results.description: Shared custody, co-parenting, share-parenting…it goes by different names. results.title: Dad's goanna
results.brief_description:
One of two stories in MAP about the stuffed animal displays in the Murtoa Museum. In this short doco, Meryl Duder talks about her life in Murtoa as a young girl of 10, relating the tale of “dad’s goanna” and how it ended up preserved in Mr Hill’s house in Murtoa in a room full of many other stuffed animals. Years later, on returning to Murtoa with her daughter and to the Murtoa Museum, Meryl was delighted to be able to point out and say “there’s dad’s goanna”.
Filmed by Malcolm McKinnon and made with the assistance of Murtoa Historical Society and Murtoa Lions Club.
The James Hill Bird Collection is held by the Lions Club of Murtoa under a special scientific license.
